documents.document: "The most important thing a father can do for his children is to love their mother." - Theodore Hesburgh
"Growth for growth's sake is the ideology of the cancer cell." - Edward Abbey
"I must say I find television very educational. The minute somebody turns it on, I go to the library and read a good book." - Groucho Marx
"Home is the place where, when you have to go there, they have to take you in." - Robert Frost
"To me, old age is always 15 years older than I am." - Bernard Baruch
"There is no end. There is no beginning. There is only the infinite passion of life." - Federico Fellini
"The chains of habit are too weak to be felt until they are too strong to be broken." - Samuel Johnson
"Destiny is not a matter of chance, it is a matter of choice; it is not a thing to be waited for, it is a thing to be achieved." - William J
"There is no worse mistake in public leadership than to hold out false hopes soon to be swept away." - Winston Churchill
"Never cut what you can untie." - Joseph Joubert
"Expect only 5% of an intelligence report to be accurate. The trick of a good commander is to isolate the 5%." - Douglas MacArthur
"There is no fatigue so wearisome as that which comes from lack of work." - Charles Haddon Spurgeon
"A smooth sea never made a skilled mariner." - English proverb
"If it doesn't absorb you, if it isn't any fun, don't do it." - D.H. Lawrence
"To know what is right and not to do it is the worst cowardice." - Confucius
"Those who make the worse use of their time are the first to complain of its shortness." - Jean De La Bruyere
"He who asks a question is a fool for a minute; he who does not remains a fool forever." - Chinese Proverb
"Too many parents make life hard for their children by trying, too zealously, to make it easy for them." - Goethe
"Times are bad. Children no longer obey their parents, and everyone is writing a book." - Cicero
"Do not bother just to be better than your contemporaries or predecessors. Try to be better than yourself." - Willam Faulkner
"The truth must dazzle gradually / Or every man be blind." - Emily Dickinson
"Your vision will become clear when you look into your heart." - Carl Jung
"The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet." - Aristotle
"There are many ways to be free. One of them is to transcend reality by imagination, as I try to do." - Anais Nin
"When you reread a classic you do not see more in the book than u did before; you see more in you than there was before." - Clifton Fadiman
The great enemy of clear language is insincerity." - George Orwell
"If you have always done it that way, it is probably wrong." - Charles Kettering
"When a person can no longer laugh at himself, it is time for others to laugh at him." - Thomas Szasz
"If you have always done it that way, it is probably wrong." - Charles Kettering
"The first sign of corruption in a society that is still alive is that the end justifies the means." - Georges Bernanos
"To be successful, the first thing to do is fall in love with your work." - Sister Mary Lauretta
"One can hope that our habit of equating 'old' with obsolete and 'new' with best will in time disappear." - Hyman Rickover
"As people grow up, they cease to play and they seem to give up the yield of pleasure which they gain from playing." - Sigmund Freud
"You've got to find the force inside you." - Joseph Campbell
"Perfectionism spells paralysis." - Winston Churchill
"Nothing will ever be attempted, if all possible objections must first be overcome." - Samuel Johnson
"Wise men talk because they have something to say; fools talk because they have to say something." - Plato
"There are two ways to slide easily through life: to believe everything or to doubt everything; both ways save us from thinking." - Theodore
"I shut my eyes in order to see." - Paul Gauguin
"A book must be an axe for the frozen sea inside of us." - Franz Kafka
"When you want to test the depths of a stream, don't use both feet." - Chinese Proverb
"In all affairs it's a healthy thing now and then to hang a question mark on the things you have long taken for granted." - Bertrand Russell
"The only people who grow old were born old to begin with." - Robert E. Sherwood
"All d great things r simple, & many can b expressed in a single word: freedom; justice; honor; duty; mercy; hope." - Sir Winston Churchill
"Was there ever any domination that did not appear natural to those who possessed it?" - John Stuart Mill
"All a man can betray is his conscience." - Joseph Conrad
"There is a point beyond which even justice becomes unjust." - Sophocles
"He that would be a leader must be a bridge." - Welsh proverb
"He that lieth down with dogs shall rise up with fleas." - Benjamin Franklin
"Man does not live by words alone, despite the fact that sometimes he has to eat them. " - Adlai Stevenson
"The art of being wise is the art of knowing what to overlook." - William James
"Will is stronger than fact: it can mold and overcome fact." - H.G. Wells
"I and the public know / What all schoolchildren learn, / Those to whom evil is done / Do evil in return." - W.H. Auden
"I had rather do and not promise than promise and not do." - Arthur Warwick
The purpose of all war is ultimately peace." - Saint Augustine
B
"Technology ... the knack of so arranging the world that we don't have to experience it." - Max Frisch
"Nothing can bring you peace but yourself." - Ralph Waldo Emerson
"The true measure of a man is how he treats someone who can do him absolutely no good." - Samuel Johnson
"Human beings are perhaps never more frightening than when they are convinced beyond doubt that they are right." - Laurens Van der Post
"Man is not the sum of what he has but the total of what he does not yet have, of what he might have." - Jean Paul Sartre
"Wall Street indexes predicted nine out of the last five recessions." - Paul A. Samuelson
"Think in the morning. Act in the noon. Eat in the evening. Sleep in the night." - William Blake
"Be the change you want to see in the world." - Mahatma Gandhi
"The more original a discovery, the more obvious it seems afterward." - Arthur Koestler
"The illusion that we are separate from one another is an optical delusion of our consciousness." - Albert Einstein
"The most dangerous of all falsehoods is a slightly distorted truth. " - G.C. Lichtenberg
"The flower that follows the sun does so even on cloudy days." - Robert Leighton
"Do good by stealth, and blush to find it fame." - Alexander
"The only function of economic forecasting is to make astrology look respectable." - John Kenneth Galbraith
"Praise, like gold and diamonds, owes its values only to its scarcity" - Samuel Johnson
"Many a man fails to become a thinker for the sole reason that his memory is too good." - Friedrich Wilhelm Nietzsche
"Have more than thou showest, / Speak less than thou knowest. " - William Shakespeare
"The mind is its own place, and in itself / Can make a heaven of hell, a hell of heaven." - John Milton
"The love of learning, the sequestered nooks, / And all the sweet serenity of books." - Henry Wadsworth Longfellow
"Nature uses as little as possible of anything." - Johannes Kepler
"Honest criticism is hard to take, particularly from a relative, a friend, an acquaintance, or a stranger." - Franklin P. Jones
"Science is organized knowledge. Wisdom is organized life." - Immanuel Kant
"By trying to make things easier for their children parents can make things much harder for them." - Mardy Grothe
"A bit of fragrance always clings to the hand that gives the rose." - Chinese proverb
"The only wisdom we can hope to acquire is the wisdom of humility: Humility is endless." - T.S Eliot
"To know how to hide one's ability is great skill." - Francois de La Rochefoucauld
"Belief like any other moving body follows the path of least resistance." - Samuel Butler
"When you have to make a choice and don't make it, that is in itself a choice." - William James
"One of the strongest characteristics of genius is the power of lighting its own fire." - John W. Foster
"Although gold dust is precious, when it gets in your eyes, it obstructs your vision." - Hsi-Tang
"One day in retrospect the years of struggle will strike you as the most beautiful." - Sigmund Freud
"Try to learn something about everything and everything about something." - T.H. Huxley
"At high tide the fish eat ants; at low tide the ants eat fish." - Thai Proverb
"Education is not the filling of a pail, but the lighting of a fire." - William Butler Yeats
"A society grows great when old men plant trees whose shade they know they shall never sit in." - Greek proverb
"I shall tell you a great secret, my friend. Do not wait for the last judgment. It takes place every day." - Albert Camus
"Many live in the ivory tower called reality; they never venture on the open sea of thought." - Francois Gautier
"There is no disguise that can for long conceal love where it exists or simulate it where it does not." - Francois de La Rochefoucauld
"The skill of writing is to create a context in which other people can think." - Edwin Schlossberg
"Love is never lost. If not reciprocated, it will flow back and soften and purify the heart." - Washington Irving
"A nation that forgets its past can function no better than an individual with amnesia." - David McCullough
"Nature never did betray the heart that loved her." - William Wordsworth
"Every man supposes himself not to be fully understood or appreciated." - Ralph Waldo Emerson
"If God created us in his own image, we have more than reciprocated." - Voltaire
